issue.title: Test Explorer auto-scroll casuses "jumping"

repository.name: xcodebuild.nvim
repository.description: Neovim plugin to Build, Debug, and Test applications created for Apple devices (iOS, macOS, watchOS, etc.)

issue.body:
I noticed that on the latest nightly Neovim build (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/tag/nightly) the Test Explorer list jumps up and down when auto-scroll reaches the bottom edge and tries to scroll it.

It doesn't happen on stable v0.9.5. Bug or misuse of API?

NVIM v0.10.0-dev-2457+ga4b444252

body:
Workaround:

```lua
for i, line in ipairs(lines) do
  vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(M.bufnr, i - 1, i, false, { line })
end
```

I've bisected it to 008154954 which was part of #24824.
cc @bfredl

The instructions above do not uniquely identify a situation. I could easily expand that script myself into _some_ complete reproduction script, but so in multiple different ways. Depending on the missing details, the current behavior might or might not actually be the desired one (a change from 0.9.5 is not enough to identify a regression).

@bfredl you didn't provide information on what is exactly missing. Reproduction steps have been provided and the video showing the situation is provided, plus you got the specific commit that changes this behavior. I think you have everything you need :).

Trivially: `OTHER_BUFFER_ID` is not defined. and it is not clear at all what that should refer to in your step 2 and 4 respectively.

It is better to just provide a complete script directly, instead of having us guess stuff, to avoid any misunderstanding.
In particular, provide `min.lua` and `test.file` so we can run `nvim --clean -u min.lua test.file` and reproduce the issue (if necessary, with add debug output).

Here is the code to reproduce it... the buffer with the content is scrolled to top after setting lines. When you focus it again, the expected scroll position is restored.

```lua
local lines = {}
for i = 1, 100 do
  lines[i] = tostring(i)
end

vim.cmd(":new")
local newBuf = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(newBuf, 0, -1, false, lines)
vim.cmd(":50")

vim.cmd("vnew")
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(newBuf, 0, -1, false, lines)
```

Thanks, it's clear now. 

I cannot reproduce however on master ( 633bf61d3) with `nvim --clean -u path/to/script.lua`. Although the behavior you describe sounds like it _could_ happen (for the same reasons as in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/27720#issuecomment-1976759033 ), am I missing something more?

Maybe it's a matter of timing.
 
When I call `:luafile path/to/script.lua` after `nvim --clean -u path/to/script.lua` it's reproducible.
